Abstract

In this paper, we initiate the study of local model reconstruction attacks in the context of Federated Learning (FL). In this scenario, an honest-but-curious adversary eavesdrops on the messages exchanged between a client and the FL aggregator, and then reconstructs the model that the client would have independently trained, which we refer to as the local model. The local model potentially overfits the clientâ€™s local dataset and can subsequently serve as a potent springboard for initiating a variety of other privacy attacks, such as reconstructing specific samples in the client dataset, inferring sensitive attributes or identifying which client stores a specific sample. Our experiments demonstrate that this indirect approachâ€”reconstructing the local model before launching attacksâ€”achieves higher success rates compared to state-of-the-art attacks, both gradient-based and model-based ones, that seek to extract sensitive information directly from FL messages. Moreover, existing approaches often face severe performance degradation when factors such as the size of the clientâ€™s local dataset, the gradient batch size or the number of local gradient updates increase, potentially limiting their effectiveness in real-world scenarios. Conversely, attacks initiated on a reconstructed local model demonstrate remarkable resilience to these variables, potentially posing a more formidable threat to user privacy.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL)Â [1, 2, 3] is a distributed machine learning strategy in which multiple devices, also known as clients, work collaboratively to train a shared model. This process, orchestrated by a central server, allows data to remain locally on each device, thereby potentially enhancing data privacy. However, recent research has indicated that an honest-but-curious adversaryâ€”e.g., the server itselfâ€”can deduce sensitive client information simply by eavesdropping on the communication exchanges between a client and the server.

Privacy attacks under an honest-but-curious adversary in the FL environment can be broadly categorized into two types: gradient-based and model-based attacks.

In the first case, the adversary works with the clientâ€™s pseudo-gradients, that is the difference between the model the client receives from the server and the model returned by the clientÂ [4].111 The pseudo-gradient is proportional to the gradient when the client performs a single gradient step. By leveraging the pseudo-gradients (hereafter simply called gradients), the adversary can reconstruct private training samples (e.g., images) as demonstrated byÂ [5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. This type of exploit is referred to as the sample reconstruction attack (SRA). However, this attack may have limited impact, especially when clients employ large batch sizes and execute multiple local gradient updates (a practice that is commonly employed to minimize communication overhead). For instance, as per [8, TableÂ 6a], the SRA success rate on the LFW dataset drops from 100% to 13% as the batch size increases from 1 to 16, and from 100% to 39% when the number of local steps rises from 1 to 9. Similarly, [9, FigureÂ 8] reports a decrease from 100% to 28% on the ImageNet dataset as the batch size grows from 1 to 48. Commenting on similar results, [10]Â recommends the use of larger batch sizes as a potential mitigation strategy against the SRA.

Leaked gradients in FL may also lead to an attribute inference attack (AIA)Â [11], provided the adversary has access to the public attributes of the victimâ€™s dataset. However, as this attack attempts to infer per-sample private attribute values while gradients combine information from multiple samples, its effectiveness is significantly diminished with larger datasets. Notably, the attack accuracy almost halves on the Genome dataset when the size of the clientâ€™s local dataset increases from 50 to 1000 samplesÂ [11, TableÂ 9].

Alternatively, the adversary could directly exploit the global model or the clientâ€™s updated model to glean private information about the client. Model-based versions of previously discussed SRA and AIA have been proposed in studies like [12] and [13, 14, 15], respectively; a model-based Source Inference Attack (SIA) has been proposed inÂ [16].

However, the effectiveness of model-based attacks typically relies on the model overfitting the clientâ€™s local data, which is generally not the case for models exchanged between the clients and the server in Federated Learning. Indeed, the shared model disseminated by the server at any communication round is an aggregate of models from numerous clients and can significantly differ from the model that a client would independently learnÂ [17, FiguresÂ 2,3]. Consequently, direct attacks on the global model may offer limited value.

The updated model from the client could potentially serve as a more viable target for a direct attack. However, Federated Learning systems are typically configured to mitigate overfitting by the clientâ€”for instance, by limiting the number of local gradient steps. This approach is critical as client overfitting could obstruct the convergence of the global model, especially considering the diversity inherent in clientsâ€™ local datasetsÂ [1, 18].

In this paper, we introduce a novel threat called the local model reconstruction attack (LMRA). In this scenario, an adversary, such as a curious server, aims to reconstruct the model that a client would have trained exclusively on its local dataset. This type of attack poses a significant risk as it allows the adversary to launch the aforementioned model-based attacks with heightened efficiency. For instance, the adversary could successfully reconstruct private facial images utilized during the FL training with a batch size of 32, a task on which existing gradient-based SRAs fail and, existing naive model-based SRAs perform much worse (refer to FigureÂ 1).

Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose a new attack, the local model reconstruction attacks for FL. The attack works for any machine learning model, e.g., neural network regression/classification, using the heuristic presented in Sec.Â 3.2. We further provide theoretical guarantees on the attack success for a linear regression model (Sec.Â 3.1).

  • â€¢

    Empirical results using realistic datasets confirm that our LMRA works well on both regression and classification tasks and that it is less sensitive to the batch size, the number of local steps, and the local dataset size. Furthermore, we show how the decoded local model obtained from LMRA may be leveraged to initiate several known attacks (e.g.,Â SRA, AIA, and SIA) with performances surpassing that of the state-of-the-art attacks (Sec.Â 4).

2.2 Threat Model

We consider an honest-but-curious adversary222In what follows, we refer to the client using female pronouns and the adversary using male pronouns, respectively., which is a standard threat model in FLÂ [23, TableÂ 7] and is commonly considered in existing literatureÂ [24, 7, 8, 9, 25, 11, 16]. This adversary is knowledgeable about the trained model structure, the loss function, and the training algorithm, and may eavesdrop on communication between the attacked client and the server but does not interfere with the training process.333 The attribute inference attack (see Sec.Â 2.3) assumes that the honest-but-curious adversary has also access to public features of samples at client cğ‘c. For instance, during training round tğ‘¡t, the adversary can inspect the messages exchanged between the server and the attacked client (denoted by cğ‘c), allowing him to recover the parameters of the global model Î¸â€‹(t)ğœƒğ‘¡\theta(t) and the updated client model Î¸câ€‹(t)subscriptğœƒğ‘ğ‘¡\theta_{c}(t) (AlgorithmÂ 1). It is worth noting that the FL server itself could act as the adversary.

When it comes to defenses against such an adversary, it is crucial to understand that traditional measures like encrypted communications are ineffective against the FL server. Although more sophisticated cryptographic techniques like secure aggregation protocolsÂ [26, 27] (which allow the server to aggregate local updates without having access to each individual update) do hide the client updated model Î¸câ€‹(t)subscriptğœƒğ‘ğ‘¡\theta_{c}(t) from the server, they come with a significant computation overheadÂ [28] and are inefficient for sparse vector aggregationÂ [23]. Moreover, these techniques can be vulnerable to poisoning attacks, as they hinder the server from detecting (and removing) potentially harmful updates from malicious clientsÂ [29, 30, 31]. For instance, [32, Sec.Â 4.4] introduces a new class of data poisoning attacks that succeed when training models with secure multiparty computation. Alternatively, Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) Â [33, 34], which provide an encrypted memory region to ensure the code has been executed faithfully and privately, can both conceal clientsâ€™ updated models and defend against poisoning attacks. However, implementing a reliable TEE platform in FL remains an open challenge due to the infrastructure resource constraints and the required communication processes needed to connect verified codesÂ [23].

In the subsequent section, we provide an overview of several well-known attacks targeting FL systems. The local model reconstruction attack proposed in this paper can be used by an honest-but-curious adversary as a preliminary step to execute these attacks.

Source inference attack (SIA)

SIA aims to identify the source of a particular training record (ğ±c,y)subscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘¦(\mathbf{x}_{c},y), i.e., the originating FL clientÂ [16]. Uncovering the source may reveal sensitive information, such as the hospital where a patient was treated. Specifically, the attack proposed inÂ [16] identifies the most likely source as the client whose updated model exhibits the smallest loss on the record (ğ±c,y)subscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘¦(\mathbf{x}_{c},y). The proposed SIA method shows a higher success rate as the updated machine learning model increasingly overfits the local datasetÂ [16, Fig.Â 2]. This finding suggests that the best candidate for carrying out the attack could potentially be the optimal local model.

Attribute inference attack (AIA)

AIA leverages public information to deduce private or sensitive attributesÂ [13, 11, 14, 15]. For example, an AIA could reconstruct a userâ€™s gender from a recommender model by having access to the userâ€™s provided ratings. Formally, each input ğ±câ€‹(i)subscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{c}(i) consists of public attributes ğ±cpâ€‹(i)superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{c}^{p}(i) and a sensitive attribute scâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘–s_{c}(i). The target value, assumed to be public, is denoted by ycpâ€‹(i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–y_{c}^{p}(i). The adversary, having access to {(ğ±cpâ€‹(i),ycpâ€‹(i)),i=1,â€¦,Sc}formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘\{(\mathbf{x}_{c}^{p}(i),y_{c}^{p}(i)),i=1,...,S_{c}\} and â„³csubscriptâ„³ğ‘{\mathcal{M}}_{c}, aims to recover the sensitive attributes scâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘–{s_{c}(i)}Â [13, 11].444In Â [14, 15], the adversary possesses additional information, including estimates of the marginals or the joint distribution of the data samples. However, in this paper, we do not consider such a more powerful adversary.

The referenceÂ [11] presents a gradient-based AIA specifically designed for the FL context. The central idea involves identifying sensitive attribute values that yield virtual gradients closely resembling the clientâ€™s model updates (referred to as pseudogradients), in terms of cosine similarity. Formally, the adversary solves the following optimization problem:

From EquationÂ (2), we observe that, since gradients incorporate information from all samples, the attack performance deteriorates in the presence of a large local dataset, as evidenced by the experiments inÂ [11].

As an alternative, the AIA can be executed directly on the model (rather than on the model pseudogradients), as initially proposed for the centralized setting inÂ [13]. Let ğ¡Î¸subscriptğ¡ğœƒ\mathbf{h}_{\theta} denote the output of model Î¸ğœƒ\theta, i.e., a real number for a regression task and a probability distribution for a classification task. where ycpâ€‹(i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–y_{c}^{p}(i) is a real number or a label one-hot-encoding for regression and classification, respectively.

We provide theoretical guarantees (AppendixÂ B.1) for the accuracy of the model-based AIA attack (ProblemÂ (3)) to least squares regression when FL clients compute full batch gradients. In particular, we show that, if the model Î¸ğœƒ\theta fits well the local data or if the sensitive attribute has significant importance on the final prediction, the attack can achieves almost 100% accuracy. This result suggests that AIA on models do not suffer the limit of AIA on gradients, namely their sensitivity to the dataset size. Furthermore, our theoretical finding motivates the adversary to trigger AIA on a model as close as possible to the optimal local model, which is more likely to overfit the local dataset.

Sample reconstruction attack (SRA)

The SRA pushes the AIA approach even further as it aims to reconstruct the entire private training dataset from the gradientsÂ [5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10] or from the modelÂ [12]. For instance, in the FL context, a well-known gradient-based SRA proposed inÂ [7] reconstructs the BğµB images in the clientâ€™s batch used at each round tâˆˆğ’¯cğ‘¡subscriptğ’¯ğ‘t\in{\mathcal{T}_{c}}. This is achieved by solving the following optimization problem:

argmax{(ğ±â€‹(i),yâ€‹(i))}i=1BcosineSimâ€‹(âˆ‚â„’c(Î¸(t),{(ğ±(i),y(i)),i=1,â€¦,B})âˆ‚Î¸â€‹(t),Î¸â€‹(t)âˆ’Î¸câ€‹(t))âˆ’Î±â€‹âˆ‘i=1BTâ€‹Vâ€‹(ğ±â€‹(i)),\operatorname*{argmax}_{\{(\mathbf{x}(i),y(i))\}_{i=1}^{B}}\textbf{cosineSim}\left(\frac{\partial{\mathcal{L}_{c}}(\theta(t),\{(\mathbf{x}(i),y(i)),i=1,...,B\})}{\partial\theta(t)},\theta(t)-\theta_{c}(t)\right)-\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{B}TV(\mathbf{x}(i)), (4)

where the image total variationÂ [35] is used as a regularization term. This attack is effective only when gradients are calculated on extremely small batchesÂ [8, 10] when the number of gradient steps is smallÂ [8] or when the adversary knows the BatchNorm statistics of the private batchÂ [10].555It is worth noting that FL training can be performed without sharing BatchNorm statistics between the clients and the serverÂ [36].

Alternatively, the SRA can be executed directly on the model for classificationÂ [12]. For example, the adversary can reconstruct one training sample for each of the Kğ¾K classes by solving the Kğ¾K optimization problems:

argmaxğ±â€‹(k)ğ¡Î¸â€‹(ğ±â€‹(k))â€‹[k],âˆ€kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,K}.subscriptargmaxğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ¡ğœƒğ±ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾\operatorname*{argmax}_{\mathbf{x}(k)}\mathbf{h}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}(k))[k],\,\,\,\forall k\in\{1,...,K\}. (5)

The model-based version of SRA is likely less sensitive to batch size and more sensitive to the model fit to the data.

3 Local Model Reconstruction Attack

In this section, we show how an honest-but-curious adversary (Sec.Â 2.2) may reconstruct the optimal local model of client cğ‘c, i.e.,Â Î¸câˆ—=argâ¡minÎ¸âˆˆâ„dâ¡â„’câ€‹(Î¸,ğ’Ÿc)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘subscriptğœƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„’ğ‘ğœƒsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\theta_{c}^{*}=\arg\min_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\mathcal{L}_{c}}(\theta,{\mathcal{D}}_{c}).

First, we prove theoretical results for linear models, showing that the adversary can perfectly reconstruct the optimal local model under deterministic FL updates and provide guarantees on the reconstruction error under stochastic FL updates (Sec.Â 3.1). Second, we propose a heuristic to perform the local model reconstruction attack for any machine learning model trained in a federated way (Sec.Â 3.2).

3.1 Guarantees for Linear Model Reconstruction

We consider that clients cooperatively train a linear regression model with quadratic loss. We refer to this setting as a federated least squares regression. Remember that a clientâ€™s design matrix has a number of rows equal to the input features of the samples in the clientâ€™s local training dataset.

We first show that the adversary can exactly reconstruct the optimal local model if the attacked client performs full-batch gradient updates, as it may be the case with the popular FedAvg algorithmÂ [1].

Proposition 1.

Consider a federated least squares regression and assume that client cğ‘c has dğ‘‘d-rank design matrix and updates the global model through full-batch gradient updates. Once the adversary eavesdrops d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 communication exchanges between client cğ‘c and the server, it can recover the clientâ€™s optimal local model by solving dğ‘‘d linear systems with d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 variables, and then with Oâ€‹(d4)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘4O(d^{4}) operations.

The reconstruction procedure is detailed in the proof of PropositionÂ 1 in Appendix B.2. We remark that the result holds independently of the number of local gradient updates performed by the client at each round.

The following proposition shows that the attack in PropositionÂ 1 is order-optimal in terms of the number of messages the adversary needs to eavesdrop. The proof is moved to AppendixÂ B.3.

Proposition 2.

Consider that FedAvg with one local step is employed for a federated least squares regression. At least one client is required to communicate with the server Î©â€‹(d)Î©ğ‘‘\Omega(d) times for the global model to be learned, and the adversary needs to eavesdrop at least Î©â€‹(d)Î©ğ‘‘\Omega(d) messages from this client to reconstruct her optimal local model.

If the attacked clientâ€™s updates are random, e.g., due to batch sampling, the adversary can still reconstruct the clientâ€™s optimal local model with high probability.

Proposition 3 (Informal statement).

Consider a federated least squares regression with a large number of clients and assume that client cğ‘c has dğ‘‘d-rank design matrix, that she updates the global model through stochastic gradient steps with sub-Gaussian noise with scale Ïƒğœ\sigma and small learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, and that global models are heterogeneous. By eavesdropping on nc>dsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘‘n_{c}>d message exchanges between client cğ‘c and the server, the adversary can reconstruct the optimal local model, denoted by Î¸câˆ—^^superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘\hat{\theta_{c}^{*}}, with error:

â€–Î¸câˆ—âˆ’Î¸câˆ—^â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·â€‹Ïƒâ€‹dâ€‹(âˆ¥Î¸câˆ—âˆ¥2+1)â€‹d+1+lnâ¡2Î´nc),Â w.p.Â â‰¥1âˆ’Î´,formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘^superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘2ğ’ªğœ‚ğœğ‘‘subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘21ğ‘‘12ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ‘Â w.p.Â 1ğ›¿\left\|\theta_{c}^{*}-\hat{\theta_{c}^{*}}\right\|_{2}\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\eta\sigma d\left(\lVert\theta_{c}^{*}\rVert_{2}+1\right)\sqrt{\frac{d+1+\ln\frac{2}{\delta}}{n_{c}}}\right),\;\;\text{ w.p. }\geq 1-\delta, (6)

by solving dğ‘‘d least squares problems with d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 variables and ncdsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘‘\frac{n_{c}}{d} points, and then with Oâ€‹(ncâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘2O(n_{c}d^{2}) operations.

The formal statement of PropositionÂ 3 and its proof are in AppendixÂ B.4.

3.2 Heuristic for Local Model Reconstruction

In this section, we present a heuristic for local model reconstruction attacks (AlgorithmÂ 2) applicable to any machine learning models trained using a Federated Learning algorithm that conforms to the framework described in AlgorithmÂ 1.

Our approach for approximately reconstructing the local model of client cğ‘c consists of two steps. First, the adversary learns a mapping function ğ’¢câ€‹(w^,â‹…)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘^ğ‘¤â‹…{\mathcal{G}}_{c}(\hat{w},\cdot) to mimic the local update rule of the client by examining the messages in â„³csubscriptâ„³ğ‘{\mathcal{M}}_{c} (see (7) in AlgorithmÂ 2). Specifically, given the server model Î¸ğœƒ\theta as input, ğ’¢câ€‹(w^,Î¸)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘^ğ‘¤ğœƒ{\mathcal{G}}_{c}(\hat{w},\theta) predicts the clientâ€™s update Î”â€‹Î¸=Î¸câˆ’Î¸Î”ğœƒsubscriptğœƒğ‘ğœƒ\Delta\theta=\theta_{c}-\theta. Second, the adversary estimates the local model of client cğ‘c as the one that minimizes âˆ¥ğ’¢câ€‹(w^,Î¸)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ’¢ğ‘^ğ‘¤ğœƒ2\left\lVert{\mathcal{G}}_{c}(\hat{w},\theta)\right\rVert^{2} (see (8) in AlgorithmÂ 2). The intuition behind this step is that the client would not update the server model (Î”â€‹Î¸=0Î”ğœƒ0\Delta\theta=0) if it coincides with its optimal local model.

When executing FedAvg using a full batch size, the exact mapping function ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c} can be accurately estimated for least squares regression and is shown to be linear (seeÂ (15) in AppendixÂ B.2). In this case, minimizing âˆ¥ğ’¢câˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ’¢ğ‘2\left\lVert{\mathcal{G}}_{c}\right\rVert^{2} corresponds to solving the linear systems mentioned in PropositionÂ 1. Therefore, the decoding algorithm in PropositionÂ 1 can be viewed as a specific instance of AlgorithmÂ 2, which, in particular, results in the correct reconstruction of the optimal local model, as proven above.

In general, the performance of our heuristic relies on two factors: 1) the effectiveness of the mapping function ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c} in mimicking the specific clientâ€™s update rule (AlgorithmÂ 1, lineÂ 8), and 2) the proximity of the estimated Î¸^^ğœƒ\hat{\theta} to the true minimizer of ProblemÂ (8) when â€–ğ’¢câ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘2||{\mathcal{G}}_{c}||^{2} is non-convex.

The first factor depends on the complexity of the learning task, the complexity of the mapping function, the randomness introduced by the clientâ€™s update rule, and the number of messages observed by the adversary. In particular, the more randomness introduced, the less accurate the estimation of ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c}, and consequently, the reconstructed local model. Privacy defenses that amplify the randomness in the original algorithm, such as adding noiseÂ [37], sub-samplingÂ [38, 39], or randomly combining data samplesÂ [40, 41], are expected to affect the performance of our local model reconstruction attack. In SectionÂ D.4, we show that this is indeed the case, but, even in presence of such privacy defenses, SIA, AIA, and SRA attacks triggered on top of the local model reconstruction attack outperform state-of-the-art attacks. In presence of noisy updates, the more messages the adversary can inspect, the closer ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c} will resemble the local update rule, resulting in a smaller model reconstruction error (as shown in PropositionÂ 3 for the federated least squares regression). At the same time, our experimental results suggest that an adversary can reconstruct a neural network model by eavesdropping on merely 10% of the messages exchanged between the client and the server throughout the entire training process. This number of messages is notably smaller than what one might expect based on the theoretical results (PropositionsÂ 1 andÂ 3). Note that one-shot FL algorithms may seem to contrast our attack, but they might release directly the optimal local modelÂ [42, 43].

The second factor is influenced by the structure of ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c}. Experiments in the next section demonstrate that our heuristic exhibits strong performance even when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c} is implemented as a neural network, which results in a highly non-convex ProblemÂ (8).

4 Experiments

Datasets and model

We consider four datasets: Flight Prices for the regression task, AdultÂ [44], Leaf SyntheticÂ [45], and AT&T datasetÂ [19] for the classification tasks. Flight Prices includes flight ticket information for the 10 largest European airlines. Adult contains records with individualsâ€™ information such as sex, age, education level; it is a popular benchmark in ML for studying inference attacks and privacyÂ [46, Tables 2â€“4][47, 32]. Leaf Synthetic is a common benchmark for federated learning. The AT&T dataset contains facial images for 40 different persons and has been considered in many privacy leakage studiesÂ [12, 48, 49, 50]. For all tasks, the model is a fully-connected 3-layer neural network. We train it also with batch normalization (BN) to show its effect on FL attacksÂ [10]. AppendixÂ C.1 provides more detailed information about these datasets and the model.

Attacks

We execute four attacks on every client involved in the FL training: Local Model Reconstruction Attack (LMRA), Attribute Inference Attack (AIA), Sample Reconstruction Attack (SRA), and Source Inference Attack (SIA).666Since AIA targets tabular dataset and SRA targets image dataset, we run AIA on Flight Prices, Adult, and Leaf Synthetic, and SRA on AT&T. The model is trained through FedAvgÂ [1] for a total number of 1000 communication rounds. The adversary inspects only 100 communication rounds. Other FL hyperparameters, attacks parameters and implementation details can be found in AppendixÂ C.2.

Evaluation Metrics

We show the average attack performance over all the clients. For LMRA, we measure the distance between the tested model and the clientâ€™s optimal local model using the recent approach ZestÂ [51]. Zest is architecture-independent and computes the cosine similarity between the explanations obtained by LIMEÂ [52] for the two models (the higher the value, the more similar to two models). For AIA, the sensitive attributes are the journey type for Flight Prices, the gender for Adult, and one synthetic binary attribute for Leaf Synthetic. The accuracy of AIA is the fraction of correctly reconstructed attributes. For SRA, we measure the quality of the reconstructed image w.r.t.Â the original one using the Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM)Â [53]. SIAâ€™s accuracy is the fraction of target records for which the source has been correctly identified.

Baselines

For LMRA, there is no state-of-the-art (SOTA) method to compare with, but the adversary could use the global model or the clientâ€™s last-returned model as proxies for the local model. We compare LMRA-enabled AIA and SRA with the most recent gradient-based AIAÂ [11] and the well-known SRAÂ [7] methods, corresponding toÂ (2) andÂ (4), respectively. For SIA, we compare our LMRA-enabled approach with the SOTA attack proposed in the original workÂ [16] that chooses as source the client whose updated model exhibits the smallest loss on the training record. We trigger the AIA, SRA, and SIA attacks not only on the local model reconstructed from LMRA, but also on its potential proxies: the global model or the last-returned model.

4.1 Experimental results

TableÂ 1 summarizes the performances of the four attacks when the neural network is trained with and without batch normalization. First, we observe that the local model reconstructed by LMRA is closer to the optimal local model than the global model and the last-returned model.777The performance of the global/last-returned/optimal local/reconstructed models on the training dataset can be found in AppendixÂ D.1. Second, AIA, SRA, and SIA performed on the LMRA reconstructed models consistently outperform the baselines. Third, although batch normalization makes all the attacks less effective as observed inÂ [10], LMRA-based attacks still outperform all the baselines.

As discussed in Sec.Â 2.3, gradient-based AIAÂ [11] and SRAÂ [7] are sensitive to the local dataset size and the batch size/local epochs, respectively. In the following, we investigate the sensitivity of the alternative model-based attacks.

Impact of the local dataset size on AIA.

In Figure Â 2, we show that the average accuracy (indicated by the green triangles) for SOTA drops from 0.76 to 0.62 for Flight Prices, from 0.77 to 0.61 for Adult, and from 0.73 to 0.58 for Leaf Synthetic. This result is expected as SOTA gradient-based AIA suffers from large datasets (see Sec.Â 2.3). On the contrary, our AIA shows stable performance. As a result, its performance advantage over SOTA increases as the dataset size increases.

Impact of batch size and the number of local epochs on SRA.

FigureÂ 3 shows that the model-based SRAs are less sensitive to the batch size and to the number of local epochs than the SOTA attack and ours outperform all the baselines in all settings, except for very small batch sizes for which it achieves similar reconstructed image quality. As the batch size or the number of local epochs increases, the performance of our attack is maintained or even improves, whereas the performance of SOTA drops by 9.29.29.2 and 5.15.15.1 p.p., respectively. AppendixÂ D.2 provides the examples of reconstructed images for the batches with 64 samples. This demonstrates that using a large batch size is not a way to weaken SRA for model-based attacks.888Note that, inÂ [10, Sec.Â 6], the authors suggest to use large batch sizes to weaken SRA. The impact of batch size and local epochs on other attacks is evaluated in AppendixÂ D.3.

Impact of the number of clients.

The previous experiments are conducted in an FL system with 10 clients. Here, we investigate how its scale influences the performance of the attacks. First, note that our theoretical results show that the success of LMRA (PropositionsÂ 1 andÂ 3) and model-based AIA (PropositionÂ 4) does not depend on the total number of clients participating in FL, at least for a federated least squares regression. For neural networks, we carried out experiments with 10 to 100 clients for LMRA, AIA, and SIA on Leaf Synthetic and 10 to 40 clients for SRA on AT&T. Results are reported in FigureÂ 4. As expected, we observe a small decrease of SIA efficiency with the number of potential sources. We also note a similar behavior for AIA SOTA. However, overall, the scale of the FL system has a limited impact on the attack performance.

Impact of defense mechanisms

In AppendixÂ D.4, we evaluate to what extent some known defenses, namely Differential PrivacyÂ [54] and MixupÂ [40], are able to mitigate the attacks. Our experiments show that even under these defense mechanisms our LMRA-based attacks outperform the baselines.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we initiate the study of a new attack for FL: the adversary reconstructs a clientâ€™s optimal local model, and then use the reconstructed model to launch known model-based attacks with high success rate. This local model reconstruction attack does not suffer from a large number of local epochs, from large batch sizes, or from large dataset size, where the gradient-based attacks in the literature do. Thus, our work provides a new angle for designing powerful attacks for FL. These improved attacks might be used by curious users to discover private information. We hope to raise awareness that more research should be done to assess the privacy risk in FL and to propose efficient defense mechanisms.

Appendix B Proofs

B.1 Theoretical guarantees on model-based AIA

Here, we give the bound for the accuracy of model-based AIA shown in ProblemÂ (3), considering a least squares regression model with binary sensitive attributes.

Proposition 4.

Let ğ¬csubscriptğ¬ğ‘\mathbf{s}_{c} be the vector including all the unknown sensitive binary attributes {scâ€‹(i),âˆ€iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,Sc}}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘–for-allğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘\{s_{c}(i),\forall i\in\{1,...,S_{c}\}\} of client cğ‘c. Let Ecsubscriptğ¸ğ‘E_{c} be the mean square error of a given ML least squares regression model Î¸ğœƒ\theta on the local dataset of client cğ‘c and Î¸â€‹[s]ğœƒdelimited-[]ğ‘ \theta[s] be the model parameter corresponding to the sensitive attribute. The accuracy to recover ğ¬csubscriptğ¬ğ‘\mathbf{s}_{c} is larger than or equal to 1âˆ’4â€‹EcÎ¸â€‹[s]214subscriptğ¸ğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘ 21-\frac{4E_{c}}{\theta[s]^{2}}.

Proof.

Let ğ±câˆˆâ„ScÃ—dsubscriptğ±ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{c}\in\mathbb{R}^{S_{c}\times d} be the design matrix with rank dğ‘‘d and ğ²câˆˆâ„Scsubscriptğ²ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘†ğ‘\mathbf{y}_{c}\in\mathbb{R}^{S_{c}} be the labels in the local dataset ğ’Ÿcsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘{\mathcal{D}}_{c} of the client cğ‘c. s^â€‹(i)={0ifÂ â€‹ğ¬~câ€‹(i)<121otherwise,âˆ€iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,Sc}.formulae-sequence^ğ‘ ğ‘–cases0ifÂ subscript~ğ¬ğ‘ğ‘–121otherwisefor-allğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘\hat{s}(i)=\begin{cases}0&\text{if }\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{c}(i)<\frac{1}{2}\\ 1&\text{otherwise}\end{cases},\,\,\,\forall i\in\{1,...,S_{c}\}. (9)

Now we start to evaluate the difference between the recovered ğ¬^csubscript^ğ¬ğ‘\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{c} and the true labels ğ¬csubscriptğ¬ğ‘\mathbf{s}_{c}. From PropositionÂ 4, we can see that the accuracy of the attack depends on the importance of the sensitive attribute in model Î¸ğœƒ\theta and how well the model fits the data. If the model fits perfectly the known data, the attack can achieve 100%percent100100\% of the accuracy on these data.

B.2 Proof of PropositionÂ 1

We start with a lemma used in PropositionÂ 1.

Lemma 1.

Let ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} be a symmetric positive definite matrix. ğˆâˆ’(ğˆâˆ’ğ€)nğˆsuperscriptğˆğ€ğ‘›\mathbf{I}-(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A})^{n} is invertible for nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0.

Proof.

Since ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} is positive definite and symmetric, it can be decomposed to ğ”â€‹Î›â€‹ğ”Tğ”Î›superscriptğ”ğ‘‡\mathbf{U}\Lambda\mathbf{U}^{T}, where ğ”ğ”T=ğˆsuperscriptğ”ğ”ğ‘‡ğˆ\mathbf{U}\mathbf{U}^{T}=\mathbf{I} and Î›Î›\Lambda is a diagonal matrix whose entries are the positive eigenvalues of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}. Thus we have

ğˆâˆ’(ğˆâˆ’ğ€)nğˆsuperscriptğˆğ€ğ‘›\displaystyle\mathbf{I}-(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A})^{n} =ğ”ğˆğ”Tâˆ’(ğ”ğˆğ”Tâˆ’ğ”â€‹Î›â€‹ğ”T)n=ğ”ğˆğ”Tâˆ’ğ”â€‹(ğˆâˆ’Î›)nâ€‹ğ”Tabsentsuperscriptğ”ğˆğ”ğ‘‡superscriptsuperscriptğ”ğˆğ”ğ‘‡ğ”Î›superscriptğ”ğ‘‡ğ‘›superscriptğ”ğˆğ”ğ‘‡ğ”superscriptğˆÎ›ğ‘›superscriptğ”ğ‘‡\displaystyle=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{I}\mathbf{U}^{T}-(\mathbf{U}\mathbf{I}\mathbf{U}^{T}-\mathbf{U}\Lambda\mathbf{U}^{T})^{n}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{I}\mathbf{U}^{T}-\mathbf{U}(\mathbf{I}-\Lambda)^{n}\mathbf{U}^{T}

Before presenting the proof, we discuss the assumptions. The first assumption can be relaxed at the cost of replacing in the proof the inverse ğ‡âˆ’1superscriptğ‡1\mathbf{H}^{-1} of the matrix ğ‡=ğ±cTâ€‹ğ±cğ‡superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{H}=\mathbf{x}_{c}^{T}\mathbf{x}_{c} by its pseudo-inverse ğ‡â€ superscriptğ‡â€ \mathbf{H}^{\dagger}. Moreover, the assumption is verified if we assume a more powerful adversary who can act as a man in the middle and modify the model sent to the client. Finally, the fourth assumption corresponds to the â€œwell-behaved data assumptionâ€ for a generic linear regression problem, which is required to be able to prove the consistency of the estimators, i.e., that they converge with probability 111 to the correct value as the number of samples diverges. Appendix C Datasets, model, and experimental setup

In this section, we provide supplementary details on the datasets and model (Sec.Â C.1), and on our experimental setup (Sec.Â C.2).

C.1 Datasets and model

Flight Prices dataset

This dataset contains booking details like origin, destination, booking time before departure, departure date, journey type (round trip or not), airline codes, and segment price, which corresponds to the target in the considered regression task. Similar datasetsÂ [64] have been used to model traveller preferences and their price elasticity. The data is split according to airlines resulting in 10 clients. The number of features in this dataset is 9. To show the dissimilarity between the clients local data distribution, the relative Euclidean distance between each clientâ€™s optimal local model and the global model is evaluatedÂ [65]. We observe from TableÂ 2 that the local data distribution of clients 0 and 6 are very different from the global distribution. This corresponds to the fact that client 0 is a business fares airline and client 6 is a basic economy fares airline. The local dataset size for each client is also given in TableÂ 2.

AdultÂ [44]

This dataset contains individual information such as sex, age, education level, family situation, and working class. This information is used to predict whether a person has an income higher than 50k$. There are 10 clients. To simulate a non-iid data distribution scenario, we distribute the records of people with a PhD degree among the first three clients according to their age. The first client owns the data of young PhDs less than 38 years old, the second client owns the data of PhDs aging between 38 and 52 years old, and the third client owns the data of PhDs elder than 52 years old. The rest of the data is uniformly distributed among the remaining clients. To show the dissimilarity between clients, the relative Euclidean distance between each clientâ€™s optimal local model is evaluated (see FigureÂ 5). We can observe that, due to our specific non-iid data distribution, the optimal local models of the first three clients are quite far from the rest of the optimal local models, which is reasonable as people with PhD degree are more likely to have a different salary prediction pattern. The number of the features in this dataset is 53 and the local dataset size of each client is given in TableÂ 3.

Leaf SyntheticÂ [45]

This dataset is designed for a classification task, for which clientsâ€™ data sets are highly heterogeneous both in terms of number of samples and of underlying statistical distribution.111111The underlying statistical distribution is determined by the number of clusters. The detailed generation procedure can be found inÂ [45, AppendixÂ A]. The number of features in this dataset is set to 100. The number of the clients is set toÂ 10. To simulate a non-iid distribution across clients, the number of clusters is set toÂ 5. The local dataset size is the same for all clients and equals to 2000.

AT&TÂ [19]

This dataset contains a set of facial images from 40 people. The database was used in the context of a face recognition project carried out in collaboration with the Speech, Vision and Robotics Group of the Cambridge University Engineering Department.

There are ten different images of each of 40 people. For some people, the images were taken at different times, varying the lighting, facial expressions (open / closed eyes, smiling / not smiling) and facial details (glasses / no glasses). All the images were taken against a dark homogeneous background with the people in an upright, frontal position (with tolerance for some side movement). The size of each image is 70x80 pixels, with 256 grey levels per pixel. There are 10 clients involved in the FL training. Each client has all the images of 4 randomly chosen people and only a subset of facial images (of size 3 or 4) of the remaining people. The local dataset size for each client is given in TableÂ 4.

Model

For Figlit Prices, Adult and Leaf Synthetic dataset, the model is a neural network with 3 hidden layers, that each has 256 neurons followed by an ReLU activation layer. For AT&T, to have a comparable model size with the other datasets, the training model is shrank to a neural network with 3 hidden layers, that each has 32 neurons followed by an ReLU activation layer.

InÂ [10], the authors claim that using batch normalizationÂ [66] in a neural network but not sharing the BatchNorm statistics of the private batch between the server and the clientsÂ [36], can weaken the attack performance in FL. Thus, the clients train also the above mentioned neural network with an extra BN layer added in front of every ReLU activation layer. Again, the corresponding BN statistics during the training are not shared between the clients and the server.

C.2 Experimental Setup

For all the FL training, the learning rate is set to 1e-2 and the number of communication rounds is set to 1000. The adversary inspects the exchanged message in every 10 communication rounds. Therefore, the size of inspected messages, i.e., |â„³c|subscriptâ„³ğ‘|{\mathcal{M}}_{c}|, is 100.

For the experiments where we vary the clientâ€™s local dataset size to different values {d1,d2,â€¦}superscriptğ‘‘1superscriptğ‘‘2â€¦\{d^{1},d^{2},...\}: Let {D1,D2,â€¦}superscriptğ·1superscriptğ·2â€¦\{D^{1},D^{2},...\} be the set of the corresponding local dataset. For datasets Flight Prices, Adult, and Leaf Synthetic, the training is done using a NVIDIA T4 GPU (an AWS instance g4dn.xlarge of 8 vCPU, 16 GB system memory). For dataset AT&T, the training is done using a NVIDIA T4 GPU (an AWS instance g4dn.8xlarge of 32 vCPU, 128 GB system memory). All our experiments are implemented using PyTorch. The additional experimental settings for the attacks are given below.

Local model reconstruction attack

TablesÂ 5,Â 6,Â 7, andÂ 8 give the details on hyper-parameters used in our heuristic (AlgorithmÂ 2) including the training of mapping function (Eq.Â 7) and the training of local update difference (Eq.Â 8) on Flight Prices, Adult, Leaf Synthetic, and AT&T datasets, respectively. The notation AxB presents a neural network with B hidden layers of A neurons each followed by one ReLU activation layer.

Attribute inference attack

For the baselineÂ [11], which aims to solve the ProblemÂ (2), we use an LBFGS optimizer with learning rate 1e-3, 1e-2, and 5e-3 for Flight Prices, Adult, and Leaf Synthetic datasets, respectively.

Sample reconstruction attack

For the baselineÂ [7] which aims to solve the ProblemÂ (4), we use an SGD optimizer with learning rate 1e-3.

For the model-based attacks, which aim to solve the ProblemÂ (5), we use an SGD optimizer with learning rate 1e-3, 1e-4 and 1e-4 for the attack triggered on the local model reconstructed from LMRA, the global model, and the last-returned model, respectively.

Source inference attack

For the baselineÂ [16], it happens that the source may be different at different round, whileÂ [16] does not provide a way to determine a final answer. In our experiment, to make their attack complete, we choose the client who has been selected the most as source, i.e.,Â argmaxcâ€²âˆˆğ’|{t|câ€²=argmincâˆˆğ’l(Î¸c(t),ğ±c,y),âˆ€tâˆˆ{0,..,Tâˆ’1}}|\operatorname*{argmax}_{c^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{C}}}|\{t|c^{\prime}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{c\in{\mathcal{C}}}l(\theta_{c}(t),\mathbf{x}_{c},y),\forall t\in\{0,..,T-1\}\}|.

D.1 Model performance

The model performance is quantified by the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE)121212 MAPE(y, y^^ğ‘¦\hat{y}) = 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=0Nâˆ’1|yiâˆ’y^i|yi1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ‘1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=0}^{N-1}\frac{|y_{i}-\hat{y}_{i}|}{y_{i}} where y is the ground truth target value, y^^ğ‘¦\hat{y} is the prediction and N represents the number of samples) for regression tasks (Flight Prices dataset), and by the model accuracy for classification tasks (Adult, Leaf Synthetic, and AT&T datasets).

D.2 Examples of images recovered from SRA when training with batch size 64

Here we show the examples of images recovered from SRA when training a fully-connected 3-layer neural network without batch normalization on AT&T dataset among 10 clients through FedAvg under batch size 64 and 1 local epoch. Image (e) is obtained by the well-known gradient-based SRAÂ [7] (ProblemÂ (4)).

D.3 Impact of batch size and of the number of local epochs on LMRA, AIA, and SIA

Here, we investigate the sensitivity of the LMRA, AIA, and SIA on the batch size (FigureÂ 6) and on the number of local epochs (FigureÂ 7). For Flight Prices, Adult, and Leaf Synthetic, default values for the number of local epochs and the batch size are 1 and 512, respectively. For AT&T, default values for the number of local epochs and the batch size are 1 and 32, respectively.

Impact of batch size

For LMRA, our attack performance (measured by the model similarity to the optimal local modelÂ [51]) improves when the batch size increases. Since large batch sizes introduce less randomness in pseudogradients, they lead to a more accurate estimation of ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘{\mathcal{G}}_{c}, and, consequently, to a more accurate reconstructed model (see discussion in Sec.Â 3.2). For the SOTA AIA, since the virtual gradient is computed based on the whole local dataset of client cğ‘c (ProblemÂ (2)), when the batch size is larger, the pseudogradient Î¸â€‹(t)âˆ’Î¸câ€‹(t)ğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘ğ‘¡\theta(t)-\theta_{c}(t) is closer to the virtual one. Therefore, as expected, we observe that AIA performance increases as the batch size increases. Overall, our LMRA-based AIA and SIA outperform the SOTA attacks in all the settings except for SIA on Leaf Synthetic with batch size 128.

Impact of the number of local epochs

Compared with the SOTA AIA, our LMRA-based AIA is much less sensitive to the number of local epochs. When the number of local epochs increases from 1 to 10, our LMRA-based AIA performance is maintained or even improves, whereas the SOTA AIA performance drops significantly. For model-based SIAs (ours and the SOTA attack), the performances are insensitive to the number of local epochs. Overall, our LMRA-based attacks outperforms the SOTA attacks in all the configurations.

D.4 The performance of attacks under defenses

To mitigate the privacy leakage, we have tested three defenses. The first one, referred to as DP, is to extend DPSGD algorithmÂ [37] that clips and adds Gaussian noises to the clientâ€™s gradients in FL. The corresponding method provides theoretical guarantees on the privacy budget (Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\delta) in sample-level differential privacyÂ [54, 67]. We used OpacusÂ [68] to incorporate a (10,10âˆ’5)10superscript105(10,10^{-5})-differentially private defense. The second one, referred to as Mixup, is to train a model on composite data samples by a linear combination of sample pairsÂ [40], e.g.,Â an average one in our implementation. Mixup was proposed to improve the generalization of ML model and recent workÂ [69] shows that it can defend against adversarial attacks. The third one, referred to as DP+Mixup, is a direct combination of the two above mechanisms. The results are given in TableÂ 10.
